scenes.background: You are on annual leave, enjoying some well-deserved time off to recharge. However, during your time away, a colleague messages you privately, saying thereâ€™s an urgent task that needs immediate attention. The request creates a dilemma as you try to balance respecting your time off while feeling the pressure to help with the urgent task. You decided to help for a short time but emphasized that you would need to hand it off to someone else after that. You informed your colleagues [Monica] and [Bob] about your decision, and now you're in a video call with them discussing the situation. After suggesting to see how much can be done quickly, [Monica] looks a bit hesitant.
scenes.description: [Bob] shifts in his chair and says, 'I appreciate your willingness to help, but this task is critical. Can you at least stay on until the critical part is done?'

options.text: I understand the urgency, but I really need to switch off soon. Can we set a hard cut-off time?
options.analysis: You acknowledge the urgency but set a boundary, showing good emotional perception and self-regulation.

options.text: Fine, I'll stay on until the critical part is done, but then I'm logging off.
options.analysis: You agreed to extend your support, showing self-regulation and social skills, but empathy and emotional perception could be improved.

options.text: I really can't extend beyond what I initially agreed. We need to find someone else.
options.analysis: You reiterated your initial stance, showing good social skills and empathy but lacking in self-regulation and motivation.
